summary.body: We've just come back from a lovely first visit to the Wood Street Restaurant and Bar. Gorgeous food, great service, wonderful setting.  When it came to paying the bill, we asked if we could pay the main part with a card but pay the service charge in cash to ensure the staff get it. We have no problem excercising this legal right in other restaurants. You may or may not be aware but whenever the service charge is paid with a card, the staff do not get it but the corporation who owns the restaurant does. Time Out Magazine wrote a piece about a year ago stating that if you want to ensure the staff who served you are rewarded with a tip, then pay the service charge in cash. Our friendly and efficient waitress asked the manager on our behalf if we could do this, but she refused. We HAD to pay it with the card.  We were shocked that the manager refused point blankly and didn't even come over to explain why but decided not to go any further, we had a lovely meal in wonderful surroundings but ended up paying the waitress some more on top of the service charge as we left, just because we felt so bad for her.  She seemed to have no idea that she was entitled to the service charge. At St Paul's Chez Gerard, our regular haunt we often pay the service charge in cash and it goes directly to the staff. NB: the manager of the Wood Street Bar is the daughter of one of the three owners, who also own other restaurants, which is probably why she didn't want the staff to get the tips but her father's company instead. When we go next week, we'll have to point blankly refuse to pay the service charge with a card or bring extra cash. I understand Wood Street Restaurant is very popular with us Barbican residents on Sundays. May I suggest, if you'd like the service charge to go to the staff (and not just the manager's family and business partners), that you consider paying it in cash and ask for this right if they refuse you. We will, as otherwise, there's no incentive for good service.  In other London restaurants (and other parts of the world, especially the States) , waiters and waitresses thrive on their good tips, it's a shame that their right to this has been eroded at our local.  Has anyone else experienced the same problem at the Wood Street or any other local restaurants?
summary.subject: Tips at the Wood Street Restaurant and Bar

summary.body: The HSBC Poultry and Princess branch - the old Midland Bank Headquarters, next to the Bank of England - closes this Friday, 20th July. This branch has one of the last great Banking Halls still in use for it's original purpose. So if you want to see it before it closes, you better go now.  If you are not a HSBC customer, don't worry, there are two entrances, one at each end of the building, you enter at one, and walk the length of the banking hall to exit at the other. The branch has been doomed since HSBC moved their headquarters to the Docklands in 2004. The offices above the hall were closed at that date, HSBC sold the building for 40m and rented the ground floor for 1m a year. It has since been sold again for 72m. Since the building is Grade 1 listed, it cannot be demolished - it's supposedly going to become a grand hotel - the Banking hall becoming the hotel lobby, with the offices above being turned into hotel rooms. The replacement HSBC branch is in an inconvenient location (for the Barbican anyway) on the corner of Queen Victoria Street and Queen Street, close to Mansion House Tube. They converted the ground floor of some offices into a branch. I wouldn't hold out much hope for any architectural interest...
summary.subject: Closure of a Grand Banking Hall - HSBC Poultry and Princess

summary.body: For those of you who are interested in what was on the school site in previous centuries, I've been doing some more research and found out the following. In the late 18th century a brewery called the Goat Brewhouse was operating. A 20 year old called Sam Whitbread starting working there, then moved to Whitbread's present site within a few years. By 1813 the Whitecross St site was a debtors' prison! It was built to separate debtors from the other prisoners who were held in Newgate, so that they (the debtors) wouldn't be led astray by hardened criminals. The medieval Jewish cemetery was further south than I thought and probably stretched from Thomas More Gardens up to Beech Street.   The dig under the marquee seems to have been completed now, although the soil being replaced is being sifted through, but there's a smaller dig opened up nearer Whitecross. No idea what's there.
summary.subject: A little more local history

summary.body: Nothing to do with Macs, rather a bit of detective work for Undercover. Last week I bought some apples labelled, both collectively and individually, as Braeburns, from Waitrose. I thought at the time that they looked pretty unlike any Braeburns I had seen before - a much too uniform deep red - but I thought, naively, that Waitrose would not have got it wrong. When I got them home it became perfectly clear from the taste and texture that they were not Braeburns, so I took them back,explained the problem, and my money was refunded without question. However, I noticed that the same apples were still on sale some days later and took it up with a member of staff who was stocking the produce shelves. I pointed out the clear difference in appearance between the loose "Braeburns" and the ones in bags, which looked as they should. His explanation was that the loose ones were grown in a different country and that was why they were different in appearance, taste and texture! When I persisted, he said he would take it up with the manager. Today the same apples were still on sale, so I'd like to know when a Braeburn is not a Braeburn!
summary.subject: Apple confusion

summary.body: Last Sunday i was passing through the Barbican Centre and thought I'd pop along to the conservatory. I hadn't been for years and was really shocked at how decrepit the place looked. Plants were falling over, some overgrown and others dying, there appeared to be a lack of any thoughtful planting, lots of random pots strewn about the place either empty or with straggeling plats in. Very little clear labelling of the plants that there were and the few labels regarding the areas that the plants were from were embarrassingly lame, giving little real information. The cacti room was closed. I felt depressed leaving the place. My thoughts about the place appear to be reflected by the comments on Babricanliving, and it's suggested that perhaps John Tusa wants to get rid of it, and therefore has cut funding and let it fall into disprepair on purpose. This would certainly be an explanation. Have anyother residents been recently and thought the same? i think it's such a wonderful place and that it's something worth saving. With some thoughtful planting and relevant, well planned labelling it could be a real educational attraction for schools etc. as well as a little haven for those attempting to escape from the city for an hour or so. In it's present state i'd never suggest to any guest visting me on a Sunday that we go. It's an embarrasment. What can we, as residents, do. except write a letter to John Tusa?
summary.subject: conservatory
